results.title: A.D. Hope
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Australia Council archival film series: writers I”.
A D Hope talks in this entertaining interview of his childhood and its influence on his poetry, and the conflict with his life as a critic and academic.

results.title: A Zoo in the trees. - [2nd ed.]
results.creator_credit: Victoria. Dept. of Education and Early Childhood Development, Rob McCubbin and Louise Jonas
results.brief_description: This program deals with the importance of forest preservation in all parts of the world as they are the life support systems for tree dwelling animals. By saving the trees we are also savings the various species which inhabit them. Groups of monkeys, apes and primative lemurs at the Royal Melbourne Zoo are intimately observed feeding, caring for their young, grooming and communicating with each other. These primates are contrasted with Australia’s tree dwelling animals - the koala, lace monitor, the grey- headed fruit bat and the green tree frog. Photographed by Frank Few and Rob McCubbin, edited by Robert Martin, script by Maree Teychenne, narrated by Desley Blanch, sound editing by David Hughes.

results.title: A Zoo in the trees
results.creator_credit: Victoria. Audio-Visual Education Centre, Rob McCubbin and Louise Jonas
results.brief_description: The trees which protect us are in imminent danger. If we don’t speak now in defence of our remaining forests, we betray our own future. Judith Wright This program deals with the importance of forest preservation in all parts of the world as they are the life support systems for tree dwelling animals. By saving the trees we are also savings the various species which inhabit them. Groups of monkeys, apes and primitive lemurs at the Royal Melbourne Zoo are intimately observed feeding, caring for their young, grooming and communicating with each other. These primates are contrasted with Australia’s tree dwelling animals, the koala, lace monitor, the grey-headed fruit bat and the green tree frog. Photographed by Frank Few and Rob McCubbin, narrated by Desley Blanch and featuring music composed and performed by Don Burrowes and aboriginal music by the Bwung-Gul Aboriginal Culture Group. Suitable for middle and upper secondary levels.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Victoria. Audio-Visual Education Centre, Rob McCubbin and Louise Jonas

results.title: A Zoo's eye view: dawn to dark
results.creator_credit: Encyclopaedia Britannica Films, Milan Herzog and James A. Oliver
results.brief_description: Depicts the drama of a typical day at the San Diego Zoo. Shows the morning visitors, lively animals, an afternoon thunderstorm, and the quiet that returns as night draws near. Suitable for primary grades.

results.title: A Young social worker speaks her mind
results.creator_credit: ONF | NFB, George C. Stoney and Terence Macartney-Filgate
results.brief_description: In an extended interview, Joanna Stern tells of her experience as a welfare worker, exposing her personal, inside view of the welfare system and how it affects the people trapped in it. She raises the question of alternatives. A film of particular use to social and welfare workers and people directly concerned with the welfare system.

results.title: A Young farmer views the problems in the Hawkes Bay Catchment District
results.creator_credit: New Zealand National Film Unit and Soil Conservation and Rivers Control Council
results.brief_description: From Te Mata Peak Summit we view the fertile plains of the Hawkes Bay catchment, touring orchards, vineyards, and sheep farms. In the rolling hills surrounding the plains the soil erosion problems present themselves and the efforts to combat them are shown and discussed. Similar problems and conservation efforts are shown on the flats - flood control is also discussed.

results.title: A Year to Remember 1956
results.brief_description: Collection of newsreel footage which made up Australia’s history in 1956 - Lord and Lady Mountbatten visit Sydney - Avalanche near Mt Kosciusko - UN Secretary Dag Hammerskjold visits Canberra Hungarian refugees arrive in Australia - Suez crisis - Salk polio vaccine Lew Hoad defeats Ken Rosewall at Wimbledon - Melbourne Olympic Games opened by Duke of Edinburgh - Australia wins record number of Olympic gold medals … and much more. Rated: G

results.title: A Year to Remember 1955
results.brief_description: Collection of newsreel footage which made up Australia’s history in 1955 -, Johnnie Ray arrives at Sydney Airport - HMAS Australia towed away for scrap - Frank Sinatra and daughter Nancy arrive in Australia - Shark attacks around Sydney - Katherine Hepburn and Robert Helpmann in Australia - Maitland hit by floods - Jack Davey and Bob Hope play golf - Australia wins Davis Cup - Darby Munro retires to become a trainer … and much more. Rated: G

results.title: A Year to Remember 1954
results.brief_description: Collection of newsreel footage which made up Australia’s history in 1954 - Royal tour of Australia- Queen attends surf carnival at Bondi - Australia wide diphtheria campaign - Hopalong Cassidy visits Australia - Lew Hoad called up for national service - Russians try to abduct Mrs Petrov - British Open won by Peter Thompson - Vancouver Empire Games Marjorie Jackson and Lorraine Crapp win gold medals - Bannister beats Landy in the mile … and much more. Rated: G
